content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I mean it's something new, i like it, pretty easy, just good for CoC!

Fun clash, I was thinking it may be difficult for a coc but I solved it in 5 minutes, 
But my code is different from yours, I only count 1 for a corner even if it have 3 or 4 walls around, yours will count up to 4 corners.
I passed all tests and validators because this case never appears perhaps you can update test an validators to meet on the 2 solutions.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: If we remove the whitespace boundary that would be more fun to this challenge. It can be solved well within 15 mins.

Took me a while to see how I would solve something like this, but then I approached it by looking at each empty space and see how many times it had 3 blocks (in corners) been non white spaces.

After looping the whole entries and adding to a count that did the trick.

Really nice!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Is an excellent clash, to solve it just apply a mask over the neighborhood of each non-white pixel in the image.

This took me 17 minutes to solve even after getting to read it here and think about it for a few minutes before opening it in the IDE. I really like it, but it feels more like an easy general puzzle than a clash.
Interesting Puzzle that requires a bit of thinking, particularily for non 90 degree corners. I think it would be more appropriate for Easy than for clash.
I liked it, very interesting
I liked it, when you take out WIP, let me know, because I want to approve this clash.

I don't think this is too hard or long. I like the level of difficulty.

Here's my solution in Python. It's pretty short, but could probably be made shorter. It passes all the tests.

from itertools import product

w = int(input())
l = int(input())
plan = [input() for _ in range(l)]

counter = 0
for x, y in product(range(w-1), range(l-1)):
    if (plan[y][x:x+2] + plan[y+1][x:x+2]).count(' ') == 1:
        counter += 1

print(counter)
I think this is making a good puzzle
Personally think this is not suited for clash of code. It would be better if you could re-classify as a general puzzle! Cheers!
I agree with dzuy, too hard for clash. Otherwise, good idea.
Really nice puzzle. It seems a bit long for a clash, however,

Thanks for feedback. I was going to ask to separate all the 90 and 270 internal angles but that is a much harder task! Just counting the 90 degree corners is much easier and I would think most clashers could solve this in time?

I made the space so that pattern matching would be easy enough for a clash, without the space it adds more complexity to a solution on the edges which would make it too difficult for a low level language. Trying to be fair to all.
Taken out of WIP
Ok. But that should be part of the challenge otherwise I don't see any fun solving this. CoC is for 15 mins which is enough for this even if we have to consider edge cases.

I don't think so... you're meant to be able to solve a clash in 5 minutes. Looking at your code, it would be hard to even type that in 5 minutes, let alone the time needed to understand the problem first.

It's a great puzzle, but very hard for a clash.

Thanks for feedback. I'm hopeful that it can be solved in 5minutes, it's a lot shorter than most clashes I've done recently! There really is just the pattern matching to perform and other languages with map functions would find this much easier, I deliberately added comments to show one method of how it was done. Adding the space around every wall should help with the solution as it removes a lot of range checks.
I think you are right. I took a closer look at your code and it actually doesn't seem that bad.
